title: Admissions Requirements | Department of Physics
raw_text:
Thank you for your interest in the graduate program in the Department of Physics at the University of California, San Diego.
Application Information
Online Graduate Application for 2026-27 opens up on September 3rd, 2025 at 12pm, PST.
If you have any questions, please email
apply@physics.ucsd.edu
.
Apply Here
Application Deadline for 2026-27 is:
December 17th, 2025
.
Entering graduate students are required to have a sound knowledge of undergraduate mechanics, electricity, and magnetism, to have had senior courses or their equivalent in atomic and quantum physics, nuclear physics, and thermodynamics, and to have taken upper-division laboratory work.
In order to process your application, we require the following documents uploaded online to your application (Please don't mail or email documents):
Official transcripts
- Scanned PDF transcripts are only acceptable for application review. If an applicant is accepted into the program, official transcripts must be submitted with the application.
Statement of Purpose
- Two-page maximum
Three letters of reference
List of upper-division STEM courses
Document
Physics Grad Admissions- Course and Textbook List Template.docx
Graduate Record Examination (GRE) Physics Subject Test
​​​​​- The advanced physics GRE is required, but the general GRE is optional for this admissions cycle. Request
ETS to report your scores to the Institute Code 4836.
Application fee-
Domestic $135.00, International $155.00; US Citizens, Permanent Residents, and Undocumented students
may
be eligible for a waiver of the application fee. For more information on eligibility and the waiver process, click
here
. International applicants are not eligible for a waiver of the application fee.
Electronic Graduate Application 2026-2027
TOEFL Score Report / the IELTS Score Report / DET Score Report (International Applicants Only)
Incomplete files and applications received after December 17th, 2025 will be considered only if space is available.
International Applicants
Foreign students from non-English speaking countries are required to demonstrate proficiency in English via the TOEFL, IELTS, or Duolingo English Test (DET).
The minimum TOEFL score required is 85 for Internet-based (iBT), and the minimum TOEFL Speaking score required is 23. The minimum International English Language Testing System (IELTS) score required is Band Score 7, and the minimum IELTS Speaking score required is 7. The minimum DET score required is 120, and the minimum DET Speaking score required is 150.
International Students whose native language is not English will be required to demonstrate English language proficiency before they may serve as teaching assistants.
TOEFL iBT Special Home Edition and IELTS Indicator
Due to the COVID-19 Pandemic, UC San Diego will be accepting the TOEFL iBT Special Home Edition test scores and IELTS Indicator test scores. Applicants who do not have in-person testing options may submit the home edition scores as an alternative.
The university-wide minimum score for the TOEFL iBT Special Home Edition is the same as the in-person TOEFL iBT minimum. Information regarding the TOEFL iBT Special Home Edition can be found on the ETS Website.
The university-wide minimum score for the IELTS Indicator is the same as the in-person IELTS minimum. Information regarding the IELTS Indicator can be found on the IELTS website.
GRE Update: Physics Subject Test REQUIRED
The General GRE will not be used in our admission decisions. However,
the Physics GRE subject test will be required
. Please self-report your score in your application and submit the official score through ETS. All applications are evaluated holistically to assess an applicant’s preparation and potential for graduate coursework and independent research.
COVID-19 Personal Statement Prompt Update
Graduate Division has created a new section to the application this year that gives applicants an opportunity to describe how COVID-19 has impacted their educational experience in relation to their academic performance, grading scale, or research experience. For example: "For the spring semester, my university let us take two classes P/NP and I chose this because..." or "For the spring quarter, my college graded all classes as P/NP and we didn't have an option for a letter grade" or "For spring term, my lab was unavailable due to campus closure so I was unable to do experiments. Instead, I worked remotely on modelling related to my research project."
This section is optional, but applicants should complete this section so we can better understand their experiences.
Some topics to consider:
How did you pursue your goals for research and advanced study in Physics during the COVID-19 pandemic?
What grading system did your university adopt during the pandemic, and how did this affect you?
Were there any classes you planned to take, or research activities you planned to pursue, but were unable to due to campus restrictions? What did you do in lieu of these?
Diagnostic Exam (if accepted into the PhD program)
Entering students must take an entrance diagnostic exam on Undergraduate Physics the summer before they start in the program. The exam will cover mechanics, electricity & magnetism, quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, & math methods. Students who are found to have serious weaknesses in preparation will be directed to enroll in appropriate undergraduate upper division courses.
Fee Waiver Program
There are a couple of fee waiver programs offered by the Division of Graduate Education and Postdoctoral Affairs (GEPA) and the Department of Physics.
Please visit the GEPA website (
https://grad.ucsd.edu/admissions/requirements/application-fee-and-fee-waiver/index.html
) to see if you are eligible for a fee waiver with them. Follow their steps to request for one of their fee waivers.
If you are not eligible for an application fee waiver through GEPA, then please follow the steps below to be considered for one of our limited number of fee waivers by our department.
Please fill out the application as much as you can
(
https://connect.grad.ucsd.edu/apply/
)
Do not submit the application nor enter any payment information
Take note of your application's reference number (you'll need that for the next step)
Fill out our
Fee Waiver Request Form
The deadline to be considered for one of the department's application fee waivers is December 1, 2025.
If selected for an application fee waiver, we will contact you with further instructions by December 5, 2025.
Revised for 2026-2027 admissions

extracted_fields.program_name: Graduate Program in the Department of Physics
extracted_fields.application_requirements: Official transcripts, Statement of Purpose, Three letters of reference, List of upper-division STEM courses, GRE Physics Subject Test, Application fee, TOEFL/IELTS/DET for international applicants.
extracted_fields.features: Diagnostic exam, core courses and electives for qualification, advanced graduate courses, teaching requirement, PhD candidacy examination, thesis defense.

Application Information Online Graduate Application for 2026-27 opens up on September 3rd, 2025 at 12pm, PST. If you have any questions, please email apply@physics.ucsd.edu . Apply Here Application Deadline for 2026-27 is: December 17th, 2025 . Entering graduate students are required to have a sound knowledge of undergraduate mechanics, electricity, and magnetism, to have had senior courses or their equivalent in atomic and quantum physics, nuclear physics, and thermodynamics, and to have taken upper-division laboratory work. In order to process your application, we require the following documents uploaded online to your application (Please don't mail or email documents): Official transcripts - Scanned PDF transcripts are only acceptable for application review. If an applicant is accepted into the program, official transcripts must be submitted with the application. For more information on eligibility and the waiver process, click here . International applicants are not eligible for a waiver of the application fee. Service courses are most commonly courses applied to other majors and/or to GEs (check your degree audit to see if the course applies). STAFF = course will be offered; instructor not yet assigned (check the Online Schedule for updates). Blank = course not offered. Faculty Directory Annual schedules are usually published in April (e.g., 2026–27 in April 2026, 2027–28 in April 2027). Typical Course Frequency and Term(s) (for long-term planning). Students are required to complete the following requirements: complete the departmental diagnostic exam prior to the start of classes, satisfactorily pass the departmental core courses and electives for qualification, complete five advanced graduate courses, a PhD candidacy examination, teaching requirement, and a final defense of the thesis as described below. Diagnostic Exam Entering students must take an entrance diagnostic exam on Undergraduate Physics. The exam will cover mechanics, electricity & magnetism, quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics & math methods. Students who are found to have serious weaknesses in preparation will be directed to enroll in appropriate undergraduate upper division courses. Core Courses and Electives for Qualification Physics students are required to take 7 core courses (PHYS 200A Theoretical Mechanics I, PHYS 201 Mathematical Methods in Physics, PHYS 203A&B Advanced Classical Electrodynamics I & II, PHYS 210A Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics, PHYS 212A&B Quantum Mechanics I & II) with a grade of B or better and two elective courses with a grade of B+ or better. Elective courses may also count toward the department’s Advanced Graduate Course requirement. Students are expected to complete these courses by the end of their 1st year with the requisite grades but will be given up to two years to complete. A department Qualification Committee will review all students and recommend corrective measures for students who do not meet the course grade standards. Students who do not qualify after two years may be asked to

Mechanics, PHYS 212A&B Quantum Mechanics I & II) with a grade of B or better and two elective courses with a grade of B+ or better. Elective courses may also count toward the department’s Advanced Graduate Course requirement. Students are expected to complete these courses by the end of their 1st year with the requisite grades but will be given up to two years to complete. A department Qualification Committee will review all students and recommend corrective measures for students who do not meet the course grade standards. Students who do not qualify after two years may be asked to leave the program. Biophysics PhD students will be expected to complete these courses by the end of their 2nd year with the requisite grades but will be given an additional year if necessary. Advanced Graduate Courses Physics Ph.D. students are required to take five advanced graduate courses (with a grade of C or better) from at least three of the groups listed below no later than the end of the third year in the program. A 3.0 in four of the five courses is required. (In lieu of the course requirement, students may petition to take an oral examination covering three areas of physics.) Note: Biophysics students select five courses from Biology, Biochemistry, Chemistry, or Physics in consultation with their adviser. At least three of these courses must be graduate courses. Physics courses are to be selected from Groups 1-8 listed below. Group 1 (Plasma) Phys 218A-B-C (Plasma) Phys 235 (Nonlinear Plasma Th) Group 2 (Cond. Matter) Phys 211A-B (Solid State) Phys 219 (Cond. Matt. Lab.) Phys 230 (Adv Solid State) Phys 232 (Electronic Materials) Group 3 (Particle Phys/High Energy) Phys 214 (Elem Part) Phys 215A-B-C (Part & Fields) Phys 222A (Exp Tech Phys) Group 4 (Mathematics) Phys 210B (Nonequil Stat Mech) Phys 221A (Adv Mech) Phys 243 (Stoch Meth) Math 210A-B-C (Math Phys) Math 259A-B-C (Geom Phys) Group 5 (Biophysics) Phys 273 (Biological Info) Phys 274 (QBio Stoch Pop Gene) Phys 275 (Fund of Biol Phys) Phys 276 (Quan Molec Bio) Phys 277 (Phys of Cell) Phys 278 (Biophys Neurons) Group 6 (Astrophysics) Phys 227 (Cosmology) Phys 228 (High Energy Astrophysics and Compact Objects) Group 7 (General) PHYS 200B (Dynamics) PHYS 202 (Estimates) PHYS 212C (QM III) PHYS 213 (Quan Info.) Phys 217 (Renorm Field Th) Phys 220 (Group Th) Phys 225A-B-C (Relativ) Group 8 (Computational) Phys 241 (Comp

Stat Mech) Phys 221A (Adv Mech) Phys 243 (Stoch Meth) Math 210A-B-C (Math Phys) Math 259A-B-C (Geom Phys) Group 5 (Biophysics) Phys 273 (Biological Info) Phys 274 (QBio Stoch Pop Gene) Phys 275 (Fund of Biol Phys) Phys 276 (Quan Molec Bio) Phys 277 (Phys of Cell) Phys 278 (Biophys Neurons) Group 6 (Astrophysics) Phys 227 (Cosmology) Phys 228 (High Energy Astrophysics and Compact Objects) Group 7 (General) PHYS 200B (Dynamics) PHYS 202 (Estimates) PHYS 212C (QM III) PHYS 213 (Quan Info.) Phys 217 (Renorm Field Th) Phys 220 (Group Th) Phys 225A-B-C (Relativ) Group 8 (Computational) Phys 241 (Comp Phys I) Phys 242 (Comp Phys II) Phys 244 (Parallel Comp) Instruction in Physics Teaching Students must complete at least one quarter of Teaching Assistantship, either in a lecture course or a laboratory course. For more information, see Teaching Requirement . Qualifying Examination and Advancement to Candidacy In order to be advanced to candidacy, students must have met the departmental requirements and obtained a faculty research supervisor. At the time of application for advancement to candidacy, a doctoral committee responsible for the remainder of the student's graduate program is appointed by the Dean of Graduate Studies & Research. The committee conducts the Ph.D. qualifying examination during which students must demonstrate the ability to engage in thesis research. Usually this involves the presentation of a plan for the thesis research project. The committee may ask questions directly or indirectly related to the project and questions on general physics which it determines to be relevant. Upon successful completion of this examination, students are advanced to candidacy and are awarded the C.Phil. Degree. For more information, see Advancement to Candidacy . Thesis Defense When students have completed their theses, they are asked to present and defend them before their doctoral committees. For more information, see Final Dissertation Defense . Physics major exceptions . See Special Topics Details . See Special Studies Enrollment Instructions: Undergraduate / Graduate Summer Offerings : usually PHYS 1ABC with Labs, PHYS 2ABC, 2BL, 2CL, 2D. No upper-division or graduate physics in summer. All courses are offered in person unless noted.
